And but if you do an in vitro reaction it's very hard to get to 100% modified no matter how hard you try. In cells in the nucleolus is always 100% so I'm really curious about how those condensation state whether and how it promotes the biogenesis and the function of ribosome modification and whether it's similarly or differently regulated as a chromatin state modifications.

meeting_annotations.transcript: I think I don't know if this is quite related but for for me and this also follows something that Gant was saying it's sort of the dynamics of crowding that's really interesting and that we we try to model and so sort of the time scales when you think about the the time scales of you know when things have to get out of the way actually in order to enable something to happen. And you know in some some of the work that we're doing on this um some has to do with with you know surface protein reorganization and so and we're also interested in doing this in the context of um the epigenome and you end up with really variable time scales you know you could you could you might have to wait a really long time or or you might just by chance you know not have to wait very long for these things to happen and so I guess back to Judith's question about measurements it's like the dynamics of that seems very very difficult to measure to actually sort of get a grip on sort of this very dynamic process of of you know things are crowded yes but they're also transiently you know uncrowded right and so so how do you actually get a grip on those dynamic processes.
